paragraph: Habib Jalib (Urdu: حبیب جالب) was a Pakistani revolutionary poet, left-wing activist who opposed martial law, authoritarianism and state oppression. Pakistani poet Faiz Ahmed Faiz said that he was the poet of the masses. He opposed military coups and administrators and was duly jailed several times.
section: N/A

paragraph: == Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

paragraph: Habib Jalib was born as Habib Ahmad on 24 March 1928 in a village near Hoshiarpur, British India. He migrated to Pakistan after the partition of India. Later he worked as a proofreader for Daily Imroze of Karachi. He was a progressive writer and soon started to grab the audience with his enthusiastic recitation of poetry. He wrote in plain language, adopted a simple style and addressed common people and issues. But the conviction behind his words, the music of his voice and his emotional energy coupled with the sensitivity of the socio-political context is what stirred the audience.
section: == Early life ==

paragraph: == Political views ==
section: == Political views ==

paragraph: How can I praise thee
section: == Political views ==

paragraph: the night of the period of shortsightedness Jalib could never reconcile with the dictatorship of Ayub Khan. So when Ayub enforced his tailor-made constitution in the country in 1962, which a former prime minister Chaudhry Muhammad Ali likened to the Clock Tower of Lyallpur, Jalib wrote the following poem:
section: == Political views ==

paragraph: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: In another incident which has become a part of the resistance folklore of the country, the Governor of West Pakistan, the Nawab of Kalabagh, invited filmstar Neelo to dance in front of Shah Reza Pahlavi of Iran. She refused and as a consequence the police was sent to force and bring her, which led to her attempting to commit suicide. This incident inspired a poem by Jalib, which was later included by Neelo's husband Riaz Shahid in the film Zarqa (1969). The poem was titled Raqs-e-Zanjeer (The dance of the chains):
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: تو کہ ناواقفِ ادبِ غلامی ہے ابھی
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: رقص زنجیر پہن کر بھی کیا جاتا ہے
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: Tu kay nawaqif-e-aadab-e-ghulami hae abhi
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: Raqs zanjeer pehan kar bhi kiya jata hai. You are not aware of the protocol of a king's court. Sometimes one has to dance (before them) with the chains on oneself. The above Nazm/Song was included in film producer Riaz Shahid's film Zarqa (1969) in Mehdi Hassan's vocals which became a super-hit film song among the public in 1969 in Pakistan.
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: " Zulm Rahay Aur Amn Bhi Ho, Kaya Mumkin Hai Tum Hi Kaho" Sung by both Noor Jehan and Mehdi Hassan in film Yeh Aman (1971), lyrics by Habib Jalib and music by A. Hameed. This film song also became very popular.
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films ==

paragraph: === Bhutto's government ===
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: In 1972 Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto came to power in Pakistan after the 1971 war with India and a new independent country called Bangladesh emerged from former East Pakistan. Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto came to power in former West Pakistan, thereafter called simply Pakistan.
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: After Bhutto's death, Habib Jalib wrote the following poem:
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: ٹوٹا ہے کہاں اس کا جادو
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: اک  نعرہ بنا  ہے اس کا لہو
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: ثابت  ہوا دھڑکن دھڑکن پر وہ شخص حکومت کرتا تھا
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: لڑتا تھا وہ اپنے جیسوں سے  ہم سے تو محبت کرتا تھا
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: His magic has not been broken
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: His blood became a slogan
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: It has been proved, that he ruled his people's hearts
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: He used to fight with the people like him (Feudal Lords), but with the (poor) people like us, he used to love.
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===

paragraph: During General Zia-ul-Haq's dictatorship, Jalib wrote a poem on Zia, in which he asked how he could write darkness as Zia ( Zia literally means light in Urdu).
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===

paragraph: ظلمت کو ضیا، صر صر کو صبا، بندے کو خدا کیا لکھنا
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===

paragraph: Darkness as light, Hot desert wind as a morning breeze
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===

paragraph: How can I write a human as God?
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Zia-ul-Haq's martial law ===

paragraph: === Benazir Bhutto's government ===
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: After General Zia-ul-Haq's death in 1988, Benazir Bhutto came to power and released Habib Jalib. Disappointed at the state of the nation, when asked if he felt any change after democracy, he said:
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: حال اب تک وہی ہیں فقیروں کے
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: دن پھرے ہیں فقط وزیروں کے
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: ہر بلاول ہے دیس کا مقروض
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: پاؤں ننگے ہیں بے نظیروں کے
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: Haal ab tak wahi hain faqiroan kay
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: Din phiray hain faqat waziroan kay
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: her Bilawal hai Dais ka maqrooz
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: paoon nangay hain Benazeeroan kayThe status of the poor is still the same
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: the days of the ministers have indeed changed
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: every Bilawal (name of the only son of Benazir Bhutto) of the country is under debt
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: while Benazirs (i.e the poor) of the country walk without shoes
section: == Habib Jalib's poems used in Pakistani films == | === Benazir Bhutto's government ===

paragraph: == Death ==
section: == Death ==

paragraph: Habib Jalib died on 12 March 1993 and laid to rest in Shah Fareed Graveyard Sabzazar Lahore.
section: == Death ==

paragraph: == Recent tributes ==
section: == Recent tributes ==

paragraph: Laal band remastered and remixed the revolutionary poem "Dastoor" in Habib Jalib's voice and included it in their 2009 album Umeed-e-Sahar.
section: == Recent tributes ==

paragraph: On 23 March 2009, President of Pakistan awarded the highest civil award (posthumously) to the legendary poet, which was received by his daughter, Tahira Habib Jalib.
section: == Recent tributes ==
